column4: Hello, I had a couple of Ubuntu questions, not just due to accessibility quesitons, for the blind Linux user, but I wanted to ask a couple of questions here just to see if you folks could help.

I know that Orca in Gnome 2.18 is the default screen-reading utility when used on the Ubuntu desktop. However, I also know that in Feisty itself, Ubuntu includes the Speakup screen reading kernel patched as modules to allow access to the console. Now, I have a couple of very spisific questions.
I wanted to ask first of all, if it is possible to edit a run level system in Ubuntu desktop after installation, to insure that it boots strate away into the text console.
Just in case you seriously do not feel like using Gnome at that moment, etc.
do you need a computer for a blind person and don't like frequent upgrades?
the problem with linux on 64bit is proprietary stuff. flash, acrobat, proprietary drivers, etc. linux itself runs very very well under 64bit
I'd use a distro with longe support cycles. ubuntu LTS, debian, RH, etc
give him kde instead. and it depends a bit what your father uses
as long as you do the admin stuff, any linus is usable for him imho
you can also give him windows via vmware or WINE
it will work too. it has mail, web and a text processing app. what more does he need?
which debian did you use and when?
look for a linux accessibility channel or better forum/mailinglist in gernal. not just ubuntu
imho, with accessibility questions, the pools is too small so ask general questions and be prepared to do your won config work is best. better results than only relying on a distro
